Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): When breeze blow, fowl yansh go open.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Hidden truth or secret eventually becomes known.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: West African & Canton trade pidgin, 19th century expression.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /wen briz blo, faʊl jæ̃ʃ go ɔpən/
First Example Sentence: When breeze blow, fowl yansh go open — all di bad thing go show one day.
Second Example Sentence: You go see truth soon — when breeze blow, fowl yansh go open sure sure.
Third Example Sentence: Dem think say dem secret safe, but when breeze blow, fowl yansh go open.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): No chop finish today, tomorrow still dey.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Don’t waste all your resources now; plan for the future.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Maritime pidgin proverb from Pearl River Delta.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /no tʃɔp finɪʃ təde, tumɔro stil de/
First Example Sentence: No chop finish today, tomorrow still dey; save money for next week wahala.
Second Example Sentence: Mama always talk say no chop finish today; future still dey wait.
Third Example Sentence: No chop finish today; tomorrow fit bring hunger.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone has limits; don’t try what’s impossible.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t do what’s beyond your ability.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in Chinese merchant pidgin moral sayings.
First Example Sentence: Fish no fit climb tree, so no force am for wetin e no sabi.
Second Example Sentence: Fish no fit climb tree, so stop try be lawyer if you no like talk.
Third Example Sentence: Fish no fit climb tree — everybody get him own gift.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: People copy what they see others doing.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from global trade creole cross-contact idiom.
First Example Sentence: Monkey see, monkey do — dat boy just copy everytin me do.
Second Example Sentence: Monkey see, monkey do — na so rumor spread fast for town.
Third Example Sentence: Monkey see, monkey do — no originality again for dis office.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): Rain no fall for one man roof alone.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Everyone faces hardship; no one is exempt.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects shared experience under colonial hardship.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /ren no fɔl fɔ wan man ruf əlon/
First Example Sentence: Rain no fall for one man roof alone, everybody get problem today.
Second Example Sentence: Rain no fall for one man roof alone; we all dey suffer same wahala.
Third Example Sentence: Rain no fall for one man roof alone; make we help each other.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): Every pot get him own black bottom.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Simple declarative; possessive and comparative idiom.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Nobody is perfect; everyone has flaws.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /ɛvri pɔt gɛt im ɔn blæk bɔtəm/
First Example Sentence: Every pot get him own black bottom; no mock another person fault.
Second Example Sentence: Even di big boss, every pot get him black bottom.
Third Example Sentence: Remember, every pot get him own black bottom — no perfect person.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): Hand wey give, na hand go receive.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: If you help others, they’ll help you too.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common in trade ethics discourse of Chinese Pidgin English.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /han we giv, na han go risiv/
First Example Sentence: Hand wey give, na hand go receive; dat why we share rice for neighbor.
Second Example Sentence: Hand wey give, na hand go receive — kindness no de waste.
Third Example Sentence: Hand wey give, na hand go receive; kindness always come back.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): If goat wear cloth, him still go smell goat.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t change your true nature.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Humorous folk saying of southern ports (Guangzhou).
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /if got wer klɔt, im stil go smɛl got/
First Example Sentence: If goat wear cloth, him still go smell goat; money no fit change bad man.
Second Example Sentence: Even with perfume, if goat wear cloth, e still smell goat.
Third Example Sentence: If goat wear cloth, him still go smell goat — no pretend to be holy.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): Coconut head no de take advice.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Stubborn people don’t listen to advice.
First Example Sentence: Coconut head no de take advice; dat pikin too stubborn.
Second Example Sentence: Dat boy get coconut head — teacher don tire for am.
Third Example Sentence: Coconut head no de take advice — he go learn by mistake.

Idiom (Chinese Pidgin English): Man wey no sleep, he go dream awake.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Rest is necessary; without it, dreams can’t happen.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Without rest, one cannot function well.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Philosophical idiom from port workers and sailors.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Chinese Pid: /man we no slip, i go drim əwek/
First Example Sentence: Man wey no sleep, he go dream awake; you need rest before you continue work.
Second Example Sentence: Man wey no sleep, he go dream awake; body no be machine.
Third Example Sentence: Man wey no sleep, he go dream awake; peace come from rest.
